Department of Electrical Engineering, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile Santiago Chile A low-complexity decision model for a Home Energy Management System is proposed to follow demand trajectory sets received from a Demand Side Response aggregator. This model is designed to reduce its computational complexity and being solved by low performance processors using available Single-Board Computers as a proof of concept. To decrease the computational complexity is proposed a two-stage model, where the first stage evaluates the hourly appliance scheduling using a relaxed set of restrictions, and the second stage evaluates a reduced set of appliances in a intra-hourly interval with a detailed characterization of the scheduled appliance properties. Simulations results show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm to follow trajectories for different sets of home appliances and operational conditions. For the studied cases, the model presents deviations in the demand for the 3.2% of the cases in the first-stage and a 12% for the second-stage model. Results show that the proposed model can schedule available appliances according to the demand aggregator requirements in a limited solving time with diverse hardware. Binary variable 1 Introduction The advances on communication networks and a cost reduction in control systems contribute to the development of demand response (DR) schemes at the residential level. In this way, flexibility available on electricity consumers can be harnessed and become a valuable resource. A required component to exploit flexibility at the residential level is the so-called Home Energy Management System (HEMS). HEMS can be defined as a technology platform that allows to the user to monitor its energy usage, manage home appliances and local energy resources according to the customer preferences, expected non-controllable demand and external signals from a Local Service Entity (LSE) or a Demand Side Response (DSR) aggregator. A central element of the HEMS are the decision models to schedule the set of available appliances according to external information, technical restrictions and comfort requests by the users. In the rest of the paper, HEMS model will be used to specify such decision models. In order to take advantage of the appliances flexibility, it is necessary to define and model the available loads and its properties. The different home appliances can be categorized as interruptible, uninterruptible or deferrable loads [1], which indicates the capacity to displace and curtail its demand over time or if the task can be stopped and restart later. A complete overview of the load properties is presented in [2], adding specific properties as interdependent tasks, operation modes and energy drain/losses in a process. About the flexibility on households, in the work of [3] is evaluated the positive and negative flexibility to make offers to the grid. A different approach to evaluate flexibility is explored in [4,5], using first a energy models to evaluate the reference scheduling of a building and a second model with a flexibility request, the difference in the energy cost between the two models can be considered as the flexibility cost to the user, that could be used to define a minimal flexibility price. HEMS and DR literature focuses on different mechanisms to model and evaluate available appliances. In [6] is proposed a day-ahead pricing HEMS model that includes soft and hard peak power limits with a 5-minute interval to schedule Electric Vehicles (EVs), Energy Storage Systems (ESS), thermal and uninterruptible loads. Charging strategies for EVs participation in ancillary services markets with a real-time controller was developed in [7], including a Model Predictive Control (MPC) trajectory following model with tracking error in their formulation. An stochastic MPC HEMS model in discussed in [8], where the renewable energy generation and temperature forecast is evaluated using chance constraints restrictions. Even, risk-averse HEMS [9] can include CVaR expressions in their objective function to evaluate the risk of loss of load in stochastic scenarios. In [10] is proposed a mixed machine learning and MILP algorithm to model the load properties and scheduling the set of available appliances. In [11] are used data-driven methods, Q-learning and Markov chains to model uncertainty associated to energy prices and reduce electricity costs, while in [12] is used Q-learning and Fuzzy Reasoning models to take scheduling decisions according to dynamical energy prices. New models are including flexibility offers and aggregator response in their formulation, as seen in [3] where a HEMS models evaluate offers to positive and negative flexibility, [13] schedules its appliances according to a flexibility request from a DSR Aggregator. The integration of the HEMS into a DR program requires the implementation of schemes for information exchange and load control. Two main paradigms in the literature are: Direct Load Control (DLC) and Indirect Load Control (ILC). In a DLC-based scheme a central agent sends control signals to each appliance, while the HEMS monitors and implements the received signals. DLC-based models are focused on HVAC control, as seen in [14–17]. By contrast, in an ILC-based model the HEMS can change its demand and appliance scheduling according to price signals received from an LSE or a DSR Aggregator, where a Real-Time Price (RTP) [7,18] or a Day-Ahead Price (DAP) [6,19] can be the signal control. In [20] over 40 HEMS ILC models are presented with different objective functions and goals. Both schemes have pros and cons. In particular, DLC schemes are more reliable in terms of harnessing loads flexibility. However, it requires the use of centralized models with potential scalability issues [21]. On the other hand, ILC-based model requires a lower computational capabilities for the aggregator at expense of less certainty of the response from the loads to the price signals [22] and increase the HEMS model complexity. A third option is to consider a hybrid scheme based on a trajectory following model, decreasing the Aggregator problem complexity respect to a DLC scheme along with improving the certainty in the flexible demand response in comparison with a price signal, but increasing the computational complexity to an ILC-based problem. A similar approach is studied for a Thermostatically Controlled Load (TCL) aggregator, as reported in [23]. In addition, to reduce the computational complexity of the model an option is divide the problem into a two-stage formulation to manage different price signals or time intervals. In [24] a two-stage model to energy scheduling with RTP and DAP signals for buildings with EVs and renewable energy is discussed, related to [25] where a Hierarchical two-stage HEMS model optimizes the energy usage with a MILP model in the first-stage and the second-stage determine optimal power setting with a rule-based controller. Furthermore, a MPC single controller with two sampling rate in microgrids [26,27] decrease the problem complexity and evaluate different dynamic network effects. Reducing the computational complexity of the decision models for a HEMS to be solved in low-performance processors is relevant in order to massify its implementation. However, this has not been the main focus on the scientific literature. Usually, decision models for HEMS based on meta-heuristic and MILP formulations presents good results in high-performance processors as a Intel Xeon or Intel Core I5 Processor [11,28,29] but does not consider the implementation on low-performance processors. Moreover, in other works the test platforms are not even described [26,30] or only indicates the used method and solve time [31]. Due to the challenges and opportunities indicated previously, this paper focuses on developing the decision models for a HEMS tailored for low-performance applications. In particular, the developed models receives as an input information about demand trajectories sent by a DSR aggregator to schedule an available set of appliances according to the load and comfort restrictions. Low computational performance Single-Board Computers (SBC) are used as a study case. In particular, the main contributions of this paper are: 1 A decision model for a HEMS focused on low computational complexity which facilitates the implementation on low-cost hardware. 2 A decision model for a HEMS considering a two-stage model tailored to implementations with a high number of flexible appliances, using a demand trajectory set delivered by a DSR Aggregator to schedule appliances and ensuring a demand profile according to the received signal 3 Load models for different appliances and evaluation horizons that can interact and change its status according to their time evolution. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 introduces the mathematical formulation for the decision models of a HEMS. Section 3 defines the test environment, data sources and appliances in the test cases. Simulations and discussion of the results with diverse SBC hardware are reported in Section 4. Finally, Section 5 provides the concluding remarks. 2 Methodology The load following formulation consists on a demand curve sent by a Demand Aggregator that the HEMS decision model can follow, changing the operational points and scheduling of the controlled appliances. A unique curve could be the optimal trajectory, assuming it is possible to quantify it, but it has practical challenges. In particular, it increases the computational complexity of the problem and requires precise information about each appliance in the household to construct an ideal optimal curve. The use of a fixed trajectory could diminish the ability of the consumer to adapt their flexibility, in short-time, to their own needs. By contrast, in the proposed model it is considered a demand trajectory set that consists on a set of allowed demand blocks per hour, as seen in Fig. 1 to extend and increase the possible set of the demand curves that the HEMS can schedule to the expected demand trajectory in comparison with a reference demand curve defined by a centralized entity, where any deviation will be penalized by the model. A DSR aggregator or a third party can modify the block size according to contractual arrangements, expected flexibility requirements, demand response services or other goals, taking advantage of the HEMS flexibility to generate additional profits or savings. This formulation also simplifies the problem faced by the aggregator in comparison with a direct control approach, by requiring only general attributes of the flexible loads to construct the trajectory demand sets for different HEMS, in accordance with the customer flexibility and preferences. In this work, the demand trajectory set will be considered as an input. In addition to the demand trajectory set, the proposed formulation considers two stages with different evaluation horizons. In the first stage, the HEMS decision model receive a demand trajectory and meteorological data to determine the offline schedule of a set of appliances for the next 24 h, at one-hour intervals. The second stage evaluate scheduled appliances in a time horizon of 2 h in order to minimize demand over the expected value and track changes in the appliances status. The first-stage problem have a simplified load model to increase the number of analyzed appliances, decreasing computational complexity of the problem and allowing the HEMS to reschedule appliances if receives a new demand trajectory. On the other hand, the second-stage problem includes a complete model of each appliance, taking advantage of a reduced set of scheduled appliances to decrease the problem complexity. In Fig. 2 is detailed each step, interaction between both stages and required data to calculate the first and second stage of the model. 2.1 First-stage problem formulation First-stage HEMS decision model evaluates and schedules a set of appliances, among which stand out thermal appliances, EV’s, interruptible and uninterruptible tasks. The proposed scheduling can change according to the received demand trajectory set, the non-controllable loads and demand forecasting. Operational and comfort constraints per appliance were simplified to decrease the number of binary variables and the problem complexity. 2.1.1 Basic energy model The objective function of the first-stage model is to minimize the demand deviations from the received trajectory band r k − , r k + for a 24-hour evaluation horizon, through scheduling of a set of appliances according to the presented restrictions below (1): (1a) min p r e , P H a c , P F a c , P u t , P p p , P e v ∑ k σ k − + σ k + (1b) s.t. The set of restrictions are presented in detail in Sections 2.1.2–2.1.4 . 2.1.2 Thermal appliances The thermal appliances depend on their previous temperature state, thermal inertia of the air mass and the external temperature to determine the evolution of the temperature in time. Only the scheduled appliances in the analyzed time-step are evaluated, reducing the problem complexity. The evaluation horizon represents 2 h HEMS operation in 30 time-step, where every time-step is equivalent to 4 min, in order to respond to changes in demand or DR requirements. 2.2.1 Second-stage energy model Second-stage problem consider two different goals in the objective function. The first is evaluate the difference in the expected demand between first and second stage problem, penalizing demand values over the expected hour demand. The second goal is to penalize the maximum deviation peak for k and k + 1 hour, multiply for a weight constant. The energy model is described in Eq. (9). Three different protocols are considered according to the time duration, assuming k as the task starting hour: • One hour or less: task operation is limited to the k hour. • Between one and two hours: The sub-hourly algorithm could take 3 possible routes. At the k − 1 hour, is evaluated only the first hour of the task. In the k hour, the task can start in k and finish in k + 1 , without additional conditions. Finally, in the k + 1 hour and previous to the decision model formulation the algorithm consider the previous operation of the task appliance and force the remaining operation on k + 1 . • Duration higher than 2 hours: the task start in the first time-step of the k hour and evaluates its operation until its end. Tasks with an operation time lower than 2 h provide a higher flexibility, even though its flexibility could produce a demand deviation. The second-stage model can modify the appliance start, so, the expected demand in k and k + 1 changes and produces a deviation from the first-stage expected demand. 2.2.4 Storage and deferrable appliances In the second-stage model, pool pumps and EV appliances need to satisfy a specific amount of energy determined by the first-stage problem, for this reason, it can be modeled by the same expressions. So, the set of restrictions PP s and EV s are expressed as a unique model in (13), where Eqs. (13a) and (13b) evaluate if the energy delivered in k , k + 1 is higher than the expected value, while (13c) calculates the energy demand per time-step. Dataport 2019. The electrical consumption of 4 different homes is considered, where each household corresponds to a representative 28-day month (March, June, September and December). In total, 112 days are evaluated. If it is considered each day as a case for the first-stage, 23 cases per day are evaluated in the second-stage (2576 cases in total). Energy consumption data from Dataport includes the energy extracted from the grid and consumption from different home appliances with a 1-minute temporal granularity. A set of home appliances are modeled based on Dataport measurements. Commercial EV models are considered on the set of EVs. For the temperature forecast, historical outdoor air temperature from NOAA NCEI Climate Normals [32] is used, data station: Los Angeles Airport. The test case generation process is divided into 2 parts: Available appliances per household and the demand trajectory generation. Appliances per house have been chosen randomly. The case generation process flowchart is shown in Fig. 3, where the generated test case includes between 7 and 13 different appliances. Only a few set of properties per appliance are considered to generate the demand trajectory sets, these properties can be found in the Appendix, presented by appliance. For cases with a higher number of appliances such as a 17 task case and multiple thermal appliances case, the generation test case follow the same process and increases the number of randomized appliances. The increase in the number of appliances per case is to understand how the decision model can respond to stressful cases, evaluating the convergence and solving time. The proposed cases will be evaluated on a Raspberry Pi 3b+ (Quad-core ARM Cortex A53 processor, USD$35). To compare the computational performance of the different SBCs the standard case will be evaluated in three platforms: Raspberry Pi Zero W (Single-core ARM11 processor, USD$10), Raspberry Pi 3b+ and Nvidia Jetson Nano (Quad-core ARM Cortex A57 processor, USD$99). Prices per SBC in retail stores at January 2021 are presented as a reference. The case studies are coded on Python using Pyomo libraries [33,34]. The solver Coin-OR CBC [35] with a 0.02 MIP GAP is chose to solve MILP problems in ARM platforms. 4 Results The proposed model schedules the appliances according to the received demand trajectory set. For illustrative purposes, the demand trajectory set, scheduling, expected and second stage real demand are shown in Fig. 4 for one day in September. The expected hourly demand is calculated by the first stage of the model and the sub-hourly mean demand is the real demand per hour, where both demand curves belong to the demand trajectory set most of the time. One of the most relevant points to use demand trajectory sets as a control signal is the capacity of the HEMS to adapt its demand per hour to the requirements from the DSR aggregator, as shown in Fig. 4, the aggregator requests two significant decreases in the demand between hour 13–14 and 17–18 and the decision model schedules its appliances to fulfill this request. The proposed decision model for a HEMS offers a feasible solution to the scheduling problem in a limited time. The first-stage mean solve time for the proposed testcase is 1.64 s with a maximum time of 12.69 s (Raspberry Pi 3b+, Cortex A-53 processor, one thread). Second-stage solving time and the reached GAP are shown in Fig. 5. The convergence GAP in the second-stage problem is reached by 96.64% of the cases, whereof 95.03% of cases converges in less than 100 s. For the remaining 3.34%, the model proposes a feasible but no optimal solution. This results indicate that the model can reschedule demand under a DSR aggregator request in less than 2 min in, at least the 95% of the studied cases; allowing the DSR aggregator to potentially participate in 5-minutes ancillary services markets or modify the time-steps duration (2, 4 and 6 min) on the second-stage problem, keeping the number of time-steps. If it is compared the expected and simulated demand, in the first-stage the simulated demand exceed the allowed demand block in the 3.2% of the studied hours, with a maximum deviation of 280 Wh. In the second-stage a demand deviation over 10% from the expected demand block occurs in less than 12% of the analyzed cases. However, cases with a high deviation percentage are mainly associated with low demand hours, deforming artificially the total deviation percentage. These effects can be seen on Fig. 6, where the standard deviation does not increases with the expected demand and can be considered as an independent value. For this reason, the proposed model could have some difficulties to follow trajectories with few appliances. Additionally, the effect of the 2-hour uninterruptible tasks and the appliance start increases the demand deviations on the second-stage, those which could be avoided if the model force the task start at the beginning of the hour, losing demand peak regulation capabilities. A second option is consider the two-hour appliances with a different model that allow to the HEMS to assign a variable demand per hour, only if the sum of the two-hour demand is the required demand by the appliance. In addition, a low demand deviation in first-stage problem could be possible if the demand trajectory generator model has enough information about appliances flexibility, user behavior, weather and other events that can change the expected demand. The proposed model is sensitive to the DSR aggregator capacity to determine a feasible trajectory for every HEMS with a minimal information, so if the Aggregator provides a complex trajectory, the HEMS could schedule multiple appliances in the same time-step, increasing the demand deviation in some cases because the actual formulation does not penalizes a demand peak in the first-stage. A plausible option is change the objective function for a piece-wise function to penalize deviations according to the demand size, but the aggregator’s capacity to model the appliance properties, user behavior and other attributes that can affect the final demand can difficult the use of additional penalties. From the analyzed appliances, the thermal appliances are the most computationally complex type of appliance due to the temperature dependence in each time-step and its operation decisions. Add an additional thermal appliance increases the convergence time according to the number of binary variables in the model, reducing the number of feasible cases. Fig. 7 shows the accumulated percentage of cases with additional appliances according to the reached GAP. The standard test case shows a high percentage of cases that reaches convergence (98%, Cortex A-53 processor, one thread). Adding a refrigerator or HVAC appliance decreases the expected convergence percentage in, at least a 10%, associated with the increase in the binary variables included in the thermal models. In comparison, deferrable, interruptible and uninterruptible appliances implies a minor computational complexity to the decision model. These reductions can be exposed by a special test that increases the number of non-thermal loads to 17 appliances, in comparison with the 10 appliances analyzed on average in the standard test case. Fig. 7 shows GAP differences between the proposed test case, new 17 appliances case and previous evaluated thermal cases. The convergence percentage for the 17 appliances test is slightly lower than the standard case and much better than the two refrigerator case, plus, the convergence difference is increased if it is compared with 2 and 3 HVAC appliance cases. Finally, standard testcase and 3 HVAC appliances cases are evaluated with different ARM processor and number of threads. The results obtained are available in Fig. 8. For the standard case, each processor reach at least a 95% of cases with the expected GAP, where the oldest processor Broadcom BCM2835 (ARM11) took 172 s, seven times more than Cortex A-57 (23 s) using one thread, while the BCM2837 processor (Cortex A-53) it takes 43 s. Using a 4-thread configuration, the required time to reach the 95% convergence decreases for the processors A-53 and A-57 to 21 and 10 s. In comparison, for the 3 HVAC case with a higher computational complexity only A-57 and 4-thread A-53 processor can reach convergence in the 90% of cases, whilst one-thread configuration cannot reach a reliable schedule (20% of cases cannot converge in the limited time). These results indicate that if it is considered only the computational performance, 4 cores Cortex A-57 and its higher computational performance can solve the proposed model in less time for a broader range of households. However, by considering SBC prices, the ARM11 and Cortex A-53 processors with one core are the best options for reduced appliance problems, increasing the HEMS availability with a lower cost in hardware. In conclusion, the proposed two-stage decision model offers a feasible solution to scheduling different set of appliances, even if the algorithm cannot reach the convergence GAP in the expected time. The difficulties to reach the GAP are increased in cases with more thermal appliances. Change the acceptable GAP from 2% to 10% for low performance boards with multiple thermal appliances boost the percentage of cases that reach convergence in 6.67% (Cortex A-53, one thread) and 8.85% (ARM11 processor) and decreases the solve time, but always considering that the proposed solution is sub-optimal. If the convergence GAP remains at 2% in the second-stage, a problem with multiple thermal appliances limits the SBC that can offer a reliable solution to boards with A-57 and multi-core processors. In contrast, the high percentage of cases that reach the expected GAP for the standard test case indicates that the proposed problem can be solved with low-cost commercial SBC, decreasing hardware cost and simplifying HEMS design, even if the number of non-thermal appliances is increased, a single-core SBC could be enough to model a household with a high number of appliances. Another important factor in the SBC choice is the resolution time. Previously it was proposed a change in the model to consider time-steps with different time intervals (2, 4 and 6 min). It could be possible to model the HEMS decision problem with a resolution time lower than a minute if is used an A-57 quad-core processor and even lower times according to the advance in technology over the years or the use of powerful (and expensive) processors x86-64. Processors like Broadcom BCM2711 (quad-core Cortex-A72) in Raspberry Pi 4 and Kirin 990 Series (octa-core Cortex-A76/A55) could be the next step in order to increase the implementability and accessibility of the decision models. In addition, other HEMS heuristics or merit order algorithms could be included in the HEMS platform, running in parallel with the proposed model. 5 Conclusions A decision model for a HEMS is proposed to follow demand trajectory sets received from a demand aggregator and formulated to be implemented in low performance ARM architecture processors, using available SBC as a proof of concept. The decision problem formulation enables the HEMS to divide the scheduling of the appliances, the evaluation of the demand per hour and energy parameters, decreasing the computational complexity to evaluate a 24-hour HEMS decision model with a 4-minute time-step (360 time intervals). Results show how the proposed model can follow different demand trajectories, scheduling the set of available appliances and evaluates sub-hourly demand, reaching convergence in at least 96% of the proposed cases with a single-core Cortex-A53 processor until a 99.5% on a quad-core Cortex-A57 processor. For multiple thermal appliances only high performance ARM processors can solve the proposed problem with a reliable percentage of convergence. The proposed model can follow the received demand trajectories with some deviations in the 3.2% of the cases for the first-stage and a 12% in the second-stage. Results obtained demonstrate the proposed HEMS decision models applicability on low-power hardware, increasing the availability of the deployment of HEMS at a lower cost. Future work includes the evaluation of the joint operation of a number of HEMS with an aggregator to quantify the systemic benefits of the proposed models in comparison to other schemes such as direct load control or real-time prices. Additionally, the consideration of daily demand modeling and load flexibility properties to evaluate HEMS participation in different ancillary services markets along with a DSR aggregator. Other avenue for future work includes taking into account distributed renewable generation and Energy Storage System (ESS) to supply demand or sell energy to the grid into the HEMS decision model, assuming that the DSR aggregator could work as a Virtual Power Plant (VPP). Stochastic formulations for the HEMS decision models can be extended by consider uncertainty in the non-controllable demand, forecast for thermal loads and renewable distributed generation. coredata.dc:description: A low-complexity decision model for a Home Energy Management System is proposed to follow demand trajectory sets received from a Demand Side Response aggregator. This model is designed to reduce its computational complexity and being solved by low performance processors using available Single-Board Computers as a proof of concept. To decrease the computational complexity is proposed a two-stage model, where the first stage evaluates the hourly appliance scheduling using a relaxed set of restrictions, and the second stage evaluates a reduced set of appliances in a intra-hourly interval with a detailed characterization of the scheduled appliance properties. Simulations results show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm to follow trajectories for different sets of home appliances and operational conditions. For the studied cases, the model presents deviations in the demand for the 3.2% of the cases in the first-stage and a 12% for the second-stage model. Results show that the proposed model can schedule available appliances according to the demand aggregator requirements in a limited solving time with diverse hardware.
coredata.dc:title: A low-complexity decision model for home energy management systems
